bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Joseph Paise, July 23, 1720

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to Joseph Paise, partner of Lyme Regis merchant, Robert Burridge, July 23, 1720, concerning tobacco shipped on board the Princess, Captain James Wyatt, and about 5 hogsheads that could not be carried by her that were shipped on board the Carter to London. Carter notes that he has drawn on Paise for the "Impost & Cockett" to the Carter's Captain, and that he has sent the account "of this affair" to Burridge.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to Joseph Paise, July 23, 1720

opener.dateline:
Rappa. [Lancaster County, Virginia]
July 23d.
1720
Mr. Jo. Paise

div1.p:
From Mr. Robt. Burridge of Lyme I am
Acquainted You are concern'd wth. him in the Brigantine
Princes, James Wyatt Mr & her Cargo, wch. fell under
my Dispose She went away a Loaded vessel & I hope
is at home long since. There was some outstanding
Tobos. wch. he could not carry Mr. Burridge order'd It to
be Shipt for London accordingly have put on board
the Carter five hhds of heavy Tobo. & have thot. advise=
=able to consign It to You accordingly a bill of Lad=
=ing for It is here inclosd, I have drawn on You
for the Impost & Cockett of this Tobo. for 11S to Captn. Kent wch. You
must pay, The Accot. of this affair is clos'd & sent to
Mr. Burridge to whom refer You & am—

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter Letter Book, 1720 July-1721 July, BR 227, Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens, San Marino, California. Printed: Wright. Letters of Robert Carter. . . . p. 38.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity.
[1] The impost was the duty imposed by Britain on imported tobacco, and the cockett was the certified document (for which a fee was charged) issued stating that the impost had been paid.
